    Dinner was the last thing he would have expected to find himself doing, but Ira had made it more than clear that her skills did not lay in the kitchen and he had found it wise not to question her. Currently she sat supervising him on the counter while he cut the onions for the soup. It had been a few weeks since he had finally retrieved his belongings and officially moved in, but he still had not quite figured out what his actual role was. Tonight it was chef, yesterday it was handyman. Most of the pack still refused to pay this newcomer any respect until he earned it. At the very least they did respect Ira and she at least pretended to answer to him. Everyone knew better and Warren was getting sick of the act.
    Her nose crinkled. "What are you making?"
    "Onion soup," Warren offered.
    "French Onion Soup?" Ira asked conversationally, her legs swinging freely off the counter. Warren tried not to look at them.
    "It is soup and I am French," Warren grumbled a moment before relaxing a little as he thought it over. "So yes, French onion soup."
    "My favorite," Ira added, although Warren wasn't really listening. Her smile widened a little. "Say something in French."
    "Un peu," Warren said sardonically.
    "What does that mean?"
    "I said 'something'."
    Ira reached out from her perch on the counter and gave her leader a good smack upside the head. "You're impossible," she complained. Was it asking too much of him to smile and be sociable once in a while? A part of her secretly still wished it had been Warren who lay dead after that fight than Jonathan. She could not and would not let that show.
    Warren looked stricken. "You 'it me."
    "You deserved it. I'll do it again too," she threatened with a sickly sweet voice. He believed her.
    "Female dog," he muttered, going back to cutting the celery now with an increased vigor.
    Ira laughed. "What? I think you meant to say bitch."
    Warren paused from his cutting to think about it. "Is that not what it means?" Seemed reasonable to use them interchangeably.
    "Well, technically yes," it was Ira's turn to think it over, "but that's not how it's used when you want to be insulting."
    "Fine. You are a bitch," he corrected himself.
    Ira laughed again. It was certainly not the response he'd been expecting and his scowl deepened considerably. "What is it this time?"
    "Nothing," Ira tried to get her giggles under control. "I've just lost all ability to take you seriously right now."
    Warren dumped the ingredients unceremoniously into the simmering base of the soup. "And it seems like you are not the only one around here who feels the same way." Warren was conflicted, while he did not truly want to be their leader at the same time he found himself expecting their respect. He should have realized the underlying issue was that they knew he didn't want to be there and were reluctant to give him any respect for it.
    "They would if they knew anything about you," Ira spoke into his thoughts. She seemed genuinely interested in helping him. She had even stood up for him on a few issues already. It was unfortunate that she had to touch on the one subject Warren had no interest in talking about.
    "They know what they need to know," Warren answered obstinately.
    "They know that you killed Johnathan as an outsider. They know you never served in a pack before. They know you're a foreigner. They know you haven't done much of anything to earn their respect, and they know you don't even want to be here with them." Ira had obviously given this a great deal of thought, Warren noted irritably. It was even more irritating that she was right.
    "I do not think a history lesson will do any good." Quite suddenly the soup required all of his immediate attention.
    "It would do me some good to hear it," Ira doggedly interjected. She wasn't giving up. Not yet. "I don't even know where you're from. Would it help if I went first?"
    "Do you want dinner tonight?" Warren was switching gears and the tone of his voice demanded that she do the same. "Stop prying and let me work. I do not want to know where you are from or what your favorite color is or even 'ow you 'ave come to be what you are. And I certainly do not want to share those things of mine with you."
    Ira slipped off the counter, no longer the casual listener she had set out to be. If looks could be coagulated into a tangible substance her's would be a highly caustic acid. Looks can't kill but she was certainly trying. "You can be a real bastard. It was a mistake to ever want to get to know a selfish, self-absorbed ass like you."
    Warren watched as she stormed off, perplexed by her strong emotional response to what was, in his opinion, a fairly practical statement. What exactly had he said? Warren mentally shrugged it off, there was dinner to be made and he was sure Ira would get over it. After all, she had said this soup was her favorite so it followed naturally to assume she'd be back for dinner.
    By the time the others of the pack had finished eating and Ira had yet to make an appearance, Warren started to feel guilty. He wasn't sure exactly what about his actions had been offensive but obviously he had said something he shouldn't have. Obviously Ira was more upset than he had wanted to admit to at first. Not having her at the table had been a poignant reminder to just how much influence she had in this rough assemblage of a community. If one thing was made obvious by her absence it was that he needed her, at least on some level. Warren frowned. He wasn't ready to admit to that quite yet.
    There was still some soup left and he prepared a bowl of it to take to her. Even if she was still upset with him she shouldn't be made to go hungry for it and perhaps he could use the soup as a peace offering. It was better than going to her empty handed. Odd, she wasn't in her room. The warehouse wasn't very big, nor was it very well organized, but Warren still didn't know all the nooks and crannies she might have gone off to for sulking pruposes. If she didn't want to be found then Warren wasn't about to make the effort to go looking. With a shrug he turned and left, heading for his own makeshift room - the very same one he had woken up in. No reason to let good soup go to waste.
    The guilt still gnawed at him as he approached, Ira had, after all, gone back with him to finally bring what little of the belongings he owned. Belongings that were now being pwed through with absolutely no regard for privavy. He immediately forgot why he had been feeling guilty.
    "Mon Dieu! What the 'ell do you think you are you doing?!"
    "Research," Ira answered with an irritating matter of factness to her voice. "Is that for me?" She asked, indicating the soup Warren held in his hand.
    Warren clutched the bowl possesively to his chest. He wasn't about to give her his fine soup after she just got finished riffling through his personal effects. "Not anymore it isn't. To think I was feeling guilty about before! Stop, enough of it, you 'ave seen enough." The misbegotten soup was set aside in favor of the photos being pulled away from her snooping hands. "You 'ad no right to be in 'ere." His glare fell to the black and white photograph of three men in military uniforms standing with their arms around each other's shoulders with wide and naive smiles plastered on their young faces. They had no idea of the horror they would witness, they had only thoughts of glory and bragging rights in their foolish heads. They would soon learn that the real badges you carried with you were the scars no one would ever be able to see. It was a private pain that she had no right to be witnessing in him.
    "Which war were those taken from?" Ira was undaunted by his previous outburst, but her voice was low and respectful. She understood that look on his face as he surveyed the picture held in his hand.
    "The Great War," he answered, reluctantly lifting his eyes from the smiling faces. "You 'ad no business looking through them."
    "Then maybe you should have made it my business. I am, like it or not, your second - your lieutenant. If the others knew you were a war hero they would undoubtedly have more respect for your command authority."
    "War hero?" Warren scoffed. "There are no such things as heros in war, there are only casualties. No one ever makes it back a hero." A hand lifted to point a finger sharply at her. "Do not ever think of me as one. This discussion is over and you are not to discuss it with the others. Any of it."
    "I just don't get it," Ira blurted out, no longer able to keep her temper under control. Warren was being such a child about this and it was time for him to be told what was to be expected of him. "You have a real chance here to gain the respect a leader deserves and you're doing nothing but hide it. You don't want them to respect you," she realized slowly then began to build momentum with the idea, "because if they respect you then you'll have a greater obligation to them to be a leader. What are you so damn afraid of?"
    "I am warning you, do not go there." Warren's glare was almost more of a plead than a threat.
    "Or what? You'll shut me out of your life? Face it Warren, we're a team and I can't keep defending you to them when I have no idea who you are. They have no idea who you are. If this is about your horrible experiences in the war, I'm sorry but we've all have encountered our own horrors. We face them as a pack, that's what families do."
    "There are some things you just do not deal with as a group. It is personal."
    "Oh grow the hell up. You are not the only one to have hardship in your life, Warren Bancroft. Julian's father was hunted down right in front of him and his mother when he tried to protect them. Johnathan lost his wife and children when he went through the change for the first time, he woke up covered in their blood. Lilian's family has disowned her but not before trying to beat her to death for being what she is, what she never asked to be. Do I need to continue or have you finally gotten the point? All of us have our own stories to tell, it makes us who we are."
    "My story 'as nothing to do with any of you. It is mine." Warren was stubborn about not getting the point Ira was trying to make and it was beginning to fray her last nerve.
    "Bullshit! You're letting your past affect our future and I'm not going to let that stand. I've let you sulk for the past few weeks and it's about damn time for you to man up and take some responsibility. I will not let this pack - this family - go to hell because of your damnable emotional constipation."
    Warren looked taken aback by her outburst, but mostly by the explicatives. Ira hardly ever swore which made it all the more impacting when she decided to. For a long moment he remained quiet, alternating his glance between her stern features and the photograph in his hand. Slowly, almost embarrassingly so, he realized that this universal truth must apply to her too. He had told her he didn't care about her past and indirectly he had been telling her he didn't care about her pain. Reaching back he grabbed the still warm soup bowl and took a few steps toward her, stretching it out like the peace offering he had intended it to be in the first place. "And what about your story?" He asked quietly when she finally accepted the soup.
    "It's not very different from the others."
    Warren made his way past her and sat on the bed. A hand patted the empty space beside him to indicate his desire for her to join him there. "I would still like to 'ear it, if you feel comfortable telling me."
    Ira seemed skeptical but she walked slowly over to where he sat all the same. A spoonfull of soup occupied her lips for a moment. "You're a good chef. Something else I didn't know about you."
    "Il y a plus que je suis disposé à vous montrer," Warren replied, his French fluent and rolling off his tongue naturally.
    "I didn't catch that," she was smiling.
    "You 'ad asked me to say something to you in French earlier. I said that there is more I am willing to show you."
    "And you mean that?" Her deep blue eyes were studying him intently, searching for any signs of deception or unwillingness in his features.
    "I would not 'ave said it otherwise." At least that part of him was true. Warren rarely, if ever, said anything that didn't need to be said or was something he had no intention of following through on. "Alors, you 'ave a story to tell."
    She couldn't possibly have argued with him over the subject of revealing personal information and then refuse to share her own, and she knew it. Luckily she didn't have as much of a problem sharing as he did. After finishing the bite of soup she was on she began. "I was born a Lycan. Both my father and my mother came from a long line of them. We lived in Rome, you can't imagine the beauty of that city that people these days miss out on." Her gaze was wistful with the memories. "Of course, it was nothing compared to the glory days of Rome, mind you. I'm not that old."
    Warren actually gave a small laugh, he even smiled - unless it was a trick of the lights or perhaps a facial twitch.
    Ira continued on. "But Rome wasn't safe. The Order is perhaps at its strongest there, I have my theories that Rome is where they began their damnable crusade. We were so happy," her voice was a resigned sigh. "We had never harmed a soul. During the full moon we would curl up at the hearth and keep to ourselves." When she noticed the frown of confusion on Warren's face she explained further. "Those who are born to this life make the change during the full moon but we keep our sense of self, we control our actions." At that she paused for another long indulgence of the soup. It wasn't easy to remember the past, especially all the painful parts of it. "I was so young. I didn't understand what was happening at first. I will never forget the way my mother shielded me with her body. She didn't give them the satisfaction of a scream, she just quietly fell at my feet. My father put up a fight until he saw her there. They never gave him the chance to mourn. He was dead well before he hit the ground." She paused there, finding the lump in her throat a little too hard to speak around. The warm soup had a calming affect and she took as much advantage of it as she could.
    "And what 'appened to you," Warren asked, his voice a low and gentle hum.
    "They took one look at me and said 'she'll starve on her own, she's just a child', and then they left. I don't know how long I stayed with their bodies. After that I learned to grow up. Rome could no longer be a home to me so I left and eventually I ended up here, to make a longer story short. Johnathan immediately saw me for what I was when we met in town, he saw that I could use a safe place to stay where I would be surrounded by those who understood me. We became close friends and he entrusted this family to me. You're a part of that family now, Warren, I just hope you can come to see that."
    At some point during her story Warren's hand had migrated slowly over to lay on top of hers, when her voice had become strained he gave her soft and slender fingers a light squeeze. He wasn't good at gestures of compassion or concern, but there were those who could bring out that long dormant side in him. Elise had been the first and now Ira. "I am sorry about what I said before. I only did not want you to share your life with me because I did not want to feel obligated to do the same in return. I never meant that you were unimportant, though...I realize now that it sounded much that way." He didn't make apologies often but he felt this was a very good time to say one.
    "I know. I only pressed the issue because I honestly do want to get to know you, and it would be beneficial for this family to know you as well. Trust me. You don't even have to say anything too personal, just give me an idea of who you are." To Warren's slight surprise her hand had turned over to reciprocate the hold. To his greater surprise he didn't find an urge to pull away nagging at him. She had nice hands.
    "I was, obviously, born in France," Warren began tentatively. He wasn't sure what he was going to tell her, none of it came easy for him. Not even naming a favorite color. It all just felt far too personal and no one should know him all that well. Maybe because if they knew him they would know enough to be disappointed by him at some point. "My parents were farmers, we mostly 'ad a vineyard. Every summer my feet would be a continuous stain of purple. Some times they were mistaken for being bruised. I do not know 'ow it started but our wine began to sell well, I was thinking of going to university, though I do not remember now what I would 'ave studied. The war broke out shortly after and my brother,Jaques - the one you see there in the picture on my right - and I signed up." Warren gave a rueful sort of laugh. "I thought I would come back with medals and impress Elise enough into marrying me. As it turned out just seeing me in a uniform was enough, frankly I think the uniform itself gave me the courage to ask. Or maybe it was because I thought I might never come back and get the chance. We were allowed one visit after training, I spent it with 'er, three months later I received a letter from 'ome - she was pregnant and I was going to be a father." His eyes were distant but at that point he forcefully looked away. If he was going to tear up it would not be in front of Ira, or anyone else for that matter. "I would never see 'im, though she named 'im Matthieu after my younger brother...he died of a fever as a child." Another pause was made, but this time his eyes settled back on the neutral position of their hands. "I will not tell you what 'appened out there. Some things are better left to memories and I do not want you picturing it."
    "Are you protecting me?" Ira's voice was soft and not confrontational at all, merely curious.
    "I am, and you do not get a say in the matter." Warren cleared his throat and continued on. "Verdun was the worst of it. We 'ad to be rotated in shifts through the trenches outside the city. It was, as they 'ave come to call it, the longest fought battle of that war. I lost bothJaques and Maurice, that picture was taken before we were sent on rotation. It was the last time I saw either of them." A swarm of emotions battled for dominance on his face before all of them were roughly thrown aside. "We thought it was going to be another adventure like the ones we would make up in the vineyards, only this time the bullets were real and there was not a call to dinner at the end of the day. It did not even matter that I lived, there was not a 'ome to go back to. There was shelling on either side, not nearly so extensive as the second war, but our farm was close to front lines. There was barely even a foundation left."
    Ira had a contemplative look on her face as she listened to him retell what had to be a very painful memory. It meant a great deal to her to be the one he shared it with. "I'm sorry about what I said before, too," she finally settled on. "You're not as much of an ass as I gave you credit for." Her thumb smoothed over the rough back of his hand. "It would be hard to want another family, but there is healing in it. No one will replace the ones we've lost, but we're together and that's all that matters now."
    Warren pulled his hand back. "I cannot be what you and your family needs. I could not protect my own family, I do not need another one. You are a very capable woman and this pack respects you. I see no reason why you should not be leading them. I would prefer if you would let me leave instead of giving me another death threat."
    Ira's patience could only take so much testing in one night and Warren seemed intent on trying to find all her limits. "You can't run away from every chance to fail. And what if I do allow you to leave, what kind of example does that set for the rest of the pack? That they can quit just because it scares them to continue? I will not let this pack fall apart because of your insecurities. Running before you can fail is failure in itself. You are capable of this and I have already told you I am willing to stand at your side, what more do you need?"
    Warren seemed to mull it over but not to the desired effect. "I never asked for this."
    "No one ever does, but you're here and you need to face it." They had been doing so well, she had really let herself think he was coming around and the disappointment was fraying her already tested nerves. "Thanks for the soup. I think I need to call it a night. Are you going to be here by morning or do I have to sleep at your door?"
    She had gotten up from the bed so his glare had to come from an upward angle and lost much of its force. "I 'ave no where else to go." The truth of that statement wouldn't hit him with its full force until she shut the door and he was alone. He really didn't have anyone or anything else to go to. Maybe it was time to stop running and this was a good of place as any to let himself settle down into. Begrudgingly he had to admit that Ira was right yet again. His first order of business would be to trust her. It would have saved him a substantial amount of aggravation.

The cell phone flipped open and was lifted to his ear. "We're clear here," Vincent was saying into it. "Yes, they've been dispatched. Cleaners are clear to go in at their discretion." A pause while he listened to the other voice. "Yes, there were juveniles present...yeah, I've dealt with them. Do you want to come up here and hold my hand while you're at it? I'm fine, Shade. It's all part of the job, remember? Just concern yourself with keeping watch. Ghost out."
    The phone clicked shut and the factitious conversation was over; Vincent's work had just begun. "The alley has been cleared. You've got maybe five minutes before they arrive and about three before I set up the distraction. Get out of here before then."
    The family huddled together on the floor slowly began to untangle themselves. Children had to be shushed as they were pried from one another.
    "Why should we trust you?" It was the father and guardian of the family understandably questioning him. He had every right to be cynical, Vincent expected no less.
    "You shouldn't, but as it stands I don't think you've got much of a choice. You can try and fight and I'll kill you in front of your family, you can stay here too long debating the issue and the cleaners will take care of it for me, or you can take the risk that I've grown bored of efficient kills and decided tonight to be more inventive and you might just get out of this with your lives." Vincent's arms lifted out slightly in a gesture he hoped would appear non-threatening. "You should know that what I'm doing is treason, my neck is on the line here, not just yours. So please, whatever you're going to do, do it fast."
    "Why? Why do you care? You work for them." The mother wasn't entirely satisfied either.
    "What does it matter? I don't have time for a story. Take your family and go." What was penance to them when it came from their would-be executioner. His motives didn't matter, the only thing that did were the results. If he could at least save one more innocent family the horrors of his organization's will then perhaps he could start sleeping better at night.
    Vincent could hear the patter of feet as the family of werewolves made their cautious way out onto the fire escape and down. He didn't need a watch to know when three minutes were up - all the time he could possibly allow them. Without ceremony Vincent lit a match and dropped it to the soaked rag at his feet and began walking at a very brisk pace for the door. For good reason, the wet cloth lit up on contact behind the hunter and snaked its flaming way along the floor ending inside a jug placed by the back wall. With the countdown still going in Vincent's head he leaped when it reached 1 with a diving roll out into the stairwell. The explosion sent flames licking overhead but Vincent was already crouched low and moving down the stairs two at a time. "That went well," he coughed to himself, more than a little impressed with his handiwork. That would mark the first homemade bomb he'd ever set off.
    Outside the flames must have been visible because there was already a clamor of people. A great distraction for a small family to escape with. As predicted his phone was angrily buzzing away in his pocket. Pausing against the wall of the staircase he flipped the phone open to answer it.
    "Yeah?" There was predictable yelling on the other end. "I don't know! The place must have been rigged. I set it off as I going to leave. Yeah...yeah I'm fine, I'm in the stairwell coming down, I shouldn't need any assistance, just keep everyone away from the building." With that said he clicked the phone shut and tucked it away and began taking the stairs two at a time again, praying he wouldn't trip and fall. Though it would be a faster way to get down from the ninth floor.
    The fire was burning far better than he had anticipated. It honestly was the first time he'd set a building on fire. What the hell was he doing? The right thing? Somehow he never figured that under any condition an outright act of terrorism was 'the right thing' to do. He had a suspicion that the family now running a few blocks away would disagree with that sentiment. Vincent had expected for this to feel different somehow. The warm and cozy sensation just wasn't there and he had to wonder if it ever would be. Then again, it was easy to feel warm with the flames licking at him from all sides but not so easy to feel cozy. He'd have to save his internal debate for another time.
    Acrid smoke was the least of his worries as he moved further down from the roaring fire overhead. Support beams of the abandoned complex gave way around him and one swung precariously close behind him and crashed into the banister setting it in flames. Perhaps burning down an old building on top of himself had not been one of his brightest ideas to date. Hopefully it wouldn't be his last one either. Each step he hit only increased his growing anxiety when he learned he still had more to go. Just one more. Just one more. Finally he was right and no sooner had he hit the landing he was off and running for the exit, coughing wickedly as he went.
    His timing could not have been any closer. Just as he felt the relief of the cold night air, the building finally gave way behind him. Vincent felt the impact lifting him into the air and the only thing to do was hope for a convenient patch of grass to land on. The only thing to welcome his fall was the unconcerned and cold cement. One thing was for certain, if he wanted to continue secretly sparing lives he needed a better cover than an apartment fire. Especially an apartment fire that took place with him still inside. He considered the lesson well learned.

    It was nearing dawn by the time Vincent crashed onto the living room couch. This time it had been a small clutch of Vampires that he had found fit to spare. It wasn't easy gathering up enough dust to convince his associates of their demise but somehow they had pulled it off. Vincent was immeasurably glad none of them had decided to have a late night snack after he was through with the deceit. Wouldn't that be the irony of it all? At least Gabriel wasn't home to see him traipsing in this early in the morning, he was sure there would have been a slurry of questions if the artist hadn't been away visiting family. It was something he did once a month and this time Vincent had forgotten to wish his grandmother well in her recovery. In consolation he was sure he would hear all about it when his roommate and friend returned. Sometimes his found himself getting curious about Gabriel's outings, especially when they took place in the middle of the week, but Gabriel accepted the odd hours Vincent kept and his own odd travel plans on the very thin explanation of being a government translator.
    The troubling part was that so very few questions were asked. In Vincent's experience the people who didn't question things that were out of the ordinary were people who lived out of the ordinary lives themselves and wouldn't enjoy questions about their lives in return. After all, wasn't that the reason he didn't pry into Gabriel's personal life because it would give him permission to pry into Vincent's? What was it, exactly, that Gabriel didn't want to be questioned about in return? What secrets might he be keeping that would make him so very understanding about Vincent wanting to keep his own? Or perhaps it was all just simple naivety. Gabriel certainly had no shortages of it.
    He was interrupted from his musing by a sound at the door that was unusual. A scraping sound as if someone were trying to-- Vincent was immediately on his feet in a ready stance. A hand slipped easily to the dagger still hanging at his belt and he made his way cautiously to the door. Someone was trying - with limited success - to pick the lock. Vincent wasn't about to give them enough time to finish. With a quick snap of his wrist he twisted the dead bolt lock open before grabbing and turning the door handle. The door was pulled inward along with the intruder but Vincent was ready and waiting for him.
    His right hand shot out to grab a hold of the intruder and adeptly tugged the man off balance and had his back pressed to Vincent's chest with the knife in his left hand quickly lifting to press along his neck.
    "Vincent! What are you--aahh!"
    Vincent almost dropped the dagger at the sound of a familiar voice. "Gabe? What are you doing trying to break in?"
    "I couldn't ha--" Gabriel gasped with another whine of pain, "get the key in." His motor skills after a night of being changed were decisively imprecise.
    It wasn't until a faint smell reached Vincent's nose that he noticed what the blade - what the silver blade - was doing to Gabriel. Immediately he let go, horrified at the possibility, and took a halting step backward. "Werewolf," he breathed out almost silently with what breath he had left after that shock. "Werewolf!" This time it was an accusation and the dagger rose back up to point at Gabriel.
    "Vincent...I can explain," Gabriel began, one hand was rubbing along the deep burn on his neck that was already beginning to heal slowly.
    "That what, you have an acute allergy to silver?! That your absences just happen to coincide during the full moon?! I can't believe this. You were my friend." Somehow in his mind Vincent had yet to reconcile the fact that he saved select members of the underkind yet had not placed them on the same level he reserved for humanity.
    "What exactly has changed, Vincent? I'm still me." Gabriel's voice was calm and Vincent thought it had no right to be. Not when he was so unnerved by it all.
    "You--" quite suddenly every argument he could think of fell just shy of his lips. Gabe did make an astonishingly good point.
    As if motivated by his lack of a response, Gabriel gained momentum. "What government translator carries a silver dagger to work?" The question was almost lightly curious if it wasn't for the prior confrontation. Vincent understood the point Gabriel was trying to make.
    "So we've lied to each other," he conceded, dropping his knife hand down to rest at his side. "I kill people like you for a living."
    Silence draped heavily between them for a long moment before Gabriel broke it finally with a simple and understated question. "So what now? Are we supposed to fight to the death in the living room?"
    Vincent couldn't help himself. A quiet chuckle emanated from his lips before he could stop it and suddenly the tense situation got just a little bit lighter. Trust it to Gabe to be able to pull something of that magnitude off. "I guess I quit. I mean, we just got that coffee table and I'm sure you did a great job with the decorating in there."
    "Can you just quit a job like that?" Gabriel had no idea the intricacies that were involved in an organization as secret dependent as the Order was.
    "No, it's not that simple. Though, I haven't exactly been doing my job lately...I'm not even sure what my job really was anymore. I really can't imagine protecting society from you, no offense." Unless the danger came from an over abundance of clay pots and cups.
    "None taken. Actually I'm a little flattered...I think." Gabriel didn't sound all that flattered, there was something else in his voice; something almost like uncertainty. He knew all too well the kind of horrors he was capable of, even if he hadn't had an incident in a very long time. The threat would always be there.
    "Where have you really been going every month," Vincent suddenly interjected as a though struck him.
    "If you promise not to hunt me down," Gabriel began with a smile on his voice. "I have an abandoned bank vault to go to. Why?"
    If Einstein's world had been shaken by the discovery that the atom could be split even after his own professions that it was an impossibility, then Vincent's world was nearly rocked in two at the revelation that a werewolf could have the wherewithal and presence of mind to lock himself up for the protection of others. It just didn't happen. It couldn't happen. And yet standing right before him was a man who broke all conceptions he had of their kind and what they were, and more importantly were not, capable of. If Gabriel could break this rule then how many others like him out there had been ruthlessly slain without question. How many of them had he been directly responsible for. Vincent must have looked as shocked as he felt because Gabriel was in the middle of repeating his name.
    "-cent. Vincent? Hey, welcome back."
    "I'm sorry. I think I need some time alone to think." With that he left Gabriel in the entry way and headed for his room. There was a great deal he needed to think about and not a whole lot of time to do it in. He had a mission coming up and the killings needed to stop.

The glass clinked on the polished wooden surface of the bar and indicated its state of emptiness to the tender standing just beyond. She was a fairly tall woman with vibrantly red hair spilling in waves around her shoulders. Whether that hair was magically altered or not was any-one's guess but they didn't dare utter a word of it to her. Not if they were attached to the particular arrangement of their facial features. Most of her patrons were not what the Commons would consider normal, not by a long shot. There were vampires sipping at blood-wine at the end of the bar, keeping their distance from the neon lights of Arcadia; a few werewolves were heatedly debating politics at another table, both were intermittently picking at a nearly raw steak;  a demi-Celestine couple tried to keep their glowing radiance to themselves as they flirted incessantly; and most peculiar of all a snowy haired hunter sat directly on the bar stool closest to the door.
    Charlotte had rules in her establishment and they were simple: no violence. One would not expect a multitude of underkind to get along with each other but then they had never met Charlotte. She had guesses as to the nature of her ancestry but no clear evidence. What was clear was that somewhere in her lineage was a very powerful fallen celestial. She was one of the Fey Children, the offspring of a mixed heritage of fallen celestials when they had roamed this planet in eons past. Like her Fey brothers and sisters she was a patchwork of characteristics, unlike the children of Shumashael, Yavechel and even Manakel. What kept the masses in good spirits despite the alcohol was her uncanny ability to turn a full grown werewolf into a blubbering schoolgirl in the space of a wicked glance. Her mental abilities seemed only to be limited by her infamously devious imagination.
  Those who stayed on her good side only saw a very generous and open spirited woman willing to talk out your troubles over a glass of strong malt ale or pint of O negative Merlot. The Hunter at the bar had felt, rather than seen, both her good side and her bad. He had learned quickly that the patrons of her bar were not to be touched and that Charlotte was an invaluable source of information. They had struck a tenuous deal that she would keep his identity to herself so long as he left his work at the door. She was no fan of the Order, but Vincent wasn't your typical agent and the two of them had, over time, come to an understanding.

 

    "Another rough night," Charlotte asked, refilling Vincent's glass with brandy.
    "Night, week, month..." Vincent murmured. "It's ironic, isn't it? To be blind in more ways than one." He seemed to hear the glass being set down and reached for it instantly. The burn of alcohol helped somehow.
    "No one's perfect, especially not you. I'm not sure what you expected out of the Order," she went on, not even bothering to keep her voice down. Everyone in the vicinity could hear their words but Charlotte made sure that they couldn't comprehend them and didn't get an unhealthy dose of curiosity out of it either. "I can tell you what I think you expected. I think you expected them to be honest about the world being black and white."
    "Thanks, that helps a lot. Throw in some 'grey area' and I'll really know what you're talking about."
    Charlotte's lips curved into a mischievous smile. "I could always show you."
    Vincent physically shuddered. "Don't ever do that again."
    "You know what I meant and I know you do. Behave and I won't torment you with pink again." It was a very good threat to make, Vincent immediately found himself less inclined to be sarcastic.
    "You're right. I expected the truth to be simple." A laugh cut off the rest of his thoughts. A derisive sort of laugh you made when the subject really wasn't amusing at all. "I'm an idiot. The truth is rarely simple. I should have known that. How can I be so..."
    "Blind?" Charlotte filled in with an amused twist of her lips.
    "You're hilarious," Vincent grumbled before his lips were otherwise occupied with drinking.
    "You were thinking it," Charlotte verbally shrugged it off.
    "I thought we agreed that you would stay out of my mind," Vincent said. He didn't sound enthused at all.
    "Liquor always loosens up thoughts. I don't have to project, you're doing it for me. So technically I'm not reading your mind at all."
    "But you are pouring the liquor," Vincent pointed out.
    "Want me to stop?"
    "No," he sighed, "no I don't."
    "That's too bad, you've already had enough."
    "The hell I have. I'm not even slurring," Vincent argued, decisively less in tune with himself than Charlotte but no less confident.
    "Actually, you are. I got tired of trying to decipher it so I gave you a little help in that department. Honestly, you were horrendous." With Vincent's cup running dry once more she took it from him, but this time she didn't fill it back up.
    "Uh-huh...Next time, just let me know I've had enough instead of feeding me more."
    "That doesn't pay the bills, love. Speaking of, I'll put this on your tab for tonight." Vincent gave a grunt of approval and she propped  her elbows up on the bar with both hands supporting her chin. "If you want my advice you'll do the right thing from here on out. Now that you know the truth you can't let it sit."
    "And what exactly is the truth? That the underkind are just as capable of being virtuous as humanity? I don't believe that. Maybe...maybe they aren't as wholly malicious as I've been taught but..." he paused with a quizzical look on his face, "you're really going to town with supplementing my vocabulary, aren't you?"
    Charlotte smiled. "Want to hear what you really sound like right now?"
    "No...I don't think I do."
    "Go home, get some rest, and think about it. I'm sure you'll realize just how far off base you are. You're on the right track, love, you just haven't opened your eyes enough. Say anything and I'll make you think you're a kitten for the rest of the night," she tacked on as a warning toward Vincent's penchant for sarcasm.
    Vincent gave an understanding smile. "You know me so well."

Chapter 3

    Sharp fangs receded back up into his gums, leaving just the tips to give the appearance of normal canines. As always, his chin didn't show a hint of crimson. He was, after all, a very dignified man and conducted eating in the same way he conducted everything else in his life; neatly, cleanly, and efficiently.  That was as to be expected from the Praotet of the Petrov House.
    "Satisfied?" a feminine voice asked as she drew away from him.
    "Quite. You are well bred, pass on my approval. I will see to it that an arrangement can be made between your family and this House." His tone indicated that their business was concluded and Ilya had to be impressed that she took the cue so well and left. A fine breed indeed.
    The sun had just recently set and Ilya Petrov was already at work managing the supply of Krovpostavshik -- humans that were bred for the purpose of being fed upon in return for lavish lifestyles provided by the Petrov House and her assets. Only the finest were chosen to be incorporated into the House and Ilya had full discretion over every detail.
    The late Autumn Russian air was beyond chilly but it would be of no consequence to the Shumashaen as he made his way from the main mansion and into the city. Moscow was always more beautiful to look on at night, he had always thought. She had changed over the years, growing more and more modern as the encroaching influences of the West had their way with his homeland. Ilya couldn't say that he minded it so much. Indoor plumbing was a marvel, even if he hadn't a need for it; his Krovpastav did.
    There was business to be attended to tonight and he would be lying if he said he was looking forward to any of it. Peace treaties were always delicate things, but at least tonight he was on the moderating side of the issue. No one would challenge House Petrov, not if they valued their station in life. It meant he had unlimited security but it also meant many others of the lesser Houses vied for his protection or for his mediation in their affairs. Most were denied. Ilya Petrov had precious little time to sit down and sort out the pathetic squabbles of the lower Houses. The reason -the only reason - that he had agreed to this was because of blood ties to the House in question. A genealogist would quite likely tear themselves bald trying to follow the 'family' lines and lineages of the vampires but Ilya was well versed in the cryptic language of blood relation.
    Vampires did not have offspring in the human sense of the word. The ones they turned - which those under the Petrov House followed a strict guideline regarding siring - carried with them a signature mark that was easily detected by others. It was very rewarding to know that every member of your House bore your mark and were under your complete control. With a single uttered command he could call his entire House to his side and they would fight with every last ounce of stolen energy they had without questioning. It took little out of the imagination to see why he was perhaps the most respected and feared of the Praotets. At least in Russia.
    "Praotet Petrov," he was greeted with the proper respect as he entered the run down building from the side alleyway. To the outsider it would look like nothing more than an old and abandoned warehouse building in the still developing industrial district. That was exactly what they wanted the commonplace members of society to see. What they didn't want them to see was the lavish interior. Decorated in fineries, this was the location known to those in their circles as an Embassy. After the blood wars of the early centuries it was agreed upon by their kind that for the sake of their survival a place could be created in every major city that they walked that was a safe zone barred from all conflict and violence. Their kind were often depicted as savage blood thirsty beasts but Ilya knew better and had to say that humanity was not much different; no matter how hard they tried to be.
    "I assume that I am the first one here?" he asked.
    "You are. I have been told to make you comfortable while you wait. I'm sure their delay is merely caused by the inconvenience in distance and not by...regrettable disagreements." In other words, Ilya translated to himself, the pair of conflicted lesser Praotets had not taken matters into their own violent hands. Yet.
    "Noted. I can make myself comfortable. Notify me once they arrive and are in a civil enough mood or do not notify me at all."
    The Embassy had a sweeping staircase that lead to the second floor and was decorated like the rest of the interior with shimmering golds and vibrant reds. Serving as a safe-haven was not the only purpose of the Embassy, it was also a library and on occasion even a hotel to visiting dignitaries and those seeking shelter from the threat of harm.In rare events it had even served as a hospital of sorts. Contrary to popular fiction, vampires could feel pain and were not immune to injury even if they were infinitely more durable than their human counterparts. Of course no medical student would even know what to do with a vampire patient, but the Embassy's trained apothecaries could work wonders with their herbal concoctions. It was more of an art than a science, in Ilya's opinion, but he had made use of them often enough to know that they were indeed skilled at what they did whether or not it was an exact science.
    Ilya had found himself a comfortable spot in the grand study of the Embassy on the second floor. A historian would have a field day if he ever found himself in the confines of this library. Ancient tomes and scrolls line the walls along with more modern texts and many, if not most, of them were historical accounts of the world told through the ever observant eyes of the Shumashaens. There was not a more accurate collection of human and underkind history than the libraries the Shumashaens kept. They were the stoic and fairly unbiased observers of the world and they were practically obsessed with keeping meticulous records.
    All records agreed that their kind, and those of their cousins, had a common celestial source. Most religions would agree that they were the regrettable spawn of fallen angels; the spawn of demons. Ilya, and his kindred, knew much better. They were the offspring of the first free-thinkers this world had ever produced; yet humanity would forever remain ignorant of it. The Order saw to that religiously. Luckily for Ilya his great mentor, Grigory Petrov, had ensured that he learned who he was and where he came from. Shumashael had been a great warrior and a trusted friend, as history told of him, willing to forgo his birthright to sit at the Table of Elders in order to enlighten mankind under the rebellion of Lucifer's design. He had created the sun in his early days as a Celestial and his genius was rewarded by the placement of his creation at the center of their system. But no amount of accomplishment could ever make up for his later treason, the least it could do was grant him reprieve from Hell but banishment from Heaven. The Great Battle had left him near death but the Elders would not be satisfied. Added to his list of punishments would be the thirst and hunger for life that could never and would never be quenched. His own creation was turned against him and the rays he had sculpted now bit and tore at his flesh. From him all Vampires were born and to him all pay respect while they suffer the same afflictions. Those who remain religiously tied to their creator called themselves the Shumashaens and the rest were content to be known as the world perceived them as Vampires.
    Reading these tomes always brought about a certain nostalgia that this Praotet was not entirely comfortable with. Ilya was spared from his memories by the arrival of the Ambassador who presided over this Embassy.
    "Praotet Petrov," his greeting was simple and to the point. Ilya appreciated that.
    "Ambassador," he greeted in kind. "I pressume our guests have arrived without incident."
    "I would not go that far," the Ambassador said. A ghost of a smile touched his lips.
    "Wonderful," Ilya replied without much enthusiasm. "Then let's get started while they are still practiced at pretending to be civil."
    "Agreed. This way," the Ambassador invited with one hand outstretched.
    The conference room was much like the rest of the Embassy in terms of style and decor. A little too flashy in Ilya's opinion but it did a very good job of commanding respect; something Ilya could appreciate. Both disgruntled parties were sitting at the end of the long rectangular table on either side of it and were busy in the endeavor of glaring each other to death. The spot at the head of the table was reserved for the leading House's Praotet and Ilya gracefully alighted the ornate chair as if it, and everything else in the room, belonged to him.
    "Now," Ilya began, his hands folding together to rest on top of the wooden table, "before we begin I have a few points of interest to make. There will only be one of you speaking at a time and only when I give you the direction to. I trust I am making myself clear." His slate grey eyes glanced about the sour faces to either side of him to be sure they were listening. When he was satisfied that they were he continued on. "Praotet Dimechev, you first."
    "Praotet Maikov is a liar and a blood traitor. I want back what is rightfully mine. He is doing business with the Yavechaens. Our enemies."
    "He lies! He always lies," Maikov spat across the table.
    "Enough, Dmitry," Ilya commanded, his voice an icy smooth glacier between the pair. "You will get your turn to speak, I promise. Unless you would like for me to make my final ruling right now."
    "No," Dmitry conceded weakly, "I do not."
    "Then keep quiet until I direct you to speak or you will not get a chance to at all. Praotet Dimechev, continue."
    It was agonizing to sit through the petty bickering of the two men who shouldn't even be calling themselves Praotets. For a while Ilya toyed with the idea of simply absorbing both Houses into his own, but these two were the best both Houses had to offer then they wouldn't be worth the trouble. Another recurring thought was more appealing but decisively illegal within the shelter of the Embassy's walls. Pity. When all had finally been said and both men seemed winded from spouting off their own pithy arguments, Ilya rose from his chair to command all attention in the room.
    "You are both contemptibly pathetic," Ilya all but spat. "When was the last time either of you picked up a tome or heard a retelling of our past?" The lack of a response disheartened him even more. He could almost see Grigory's disdainful frown pulling at the ghost of his mentor's lips. He would give these two a speech that would make even Grisha proud. "I see." Ilya directed his piercing glare toward the man on his right. "Dimechev, you are a fool and worse than that you are ignorant of it. The Yavechaens are our cousins, not our enemies. You are confusing yourself with their other sect, the Werewolves. Educate yourself on the difference before you open that mouth of yours." His glare snapped over to the other side of the table. "Quit that ridiculous smirking, Maikov, you are no better. You are dealing with the Wolves and not the Yavechaens. I suggest you acquaint yourself with the distinction as well." Ilya took a breath to repress the urge to mentally annihilate them both. "Praotet Maikov, you will repay Praotet Dimechev what he is owed and then you will both do a little research. Because if I find that you have made this same mistake again I will not be inclined to settle your differences for you. Dismissed."
    On his way out of the Embassy, Ilya gave pause to consider visiting one of the resident apothecaries for something strong to cure the headache the two had caused him. Pride, and a dash of impatience to get out of there, kept him walking toward the manor. Like the Embassy, the Petrov Manor looked like nothing more than an abandon smelting factory from the outset, but Ilya could see what was just beneath the surface of that image. Spindling towers rose where smokestacks could be seen, decorated in the Gothic style in which it was first constructed. He had seen no reason to change it when he had taken over as Praotet. The gargoyle structures had character and history, even if they were just a bit too stereotypical for his tastes. His other manor in New York City was much more modern and more styled to his tastes. Perhaps it was about time to head back to his other interests across the globe. Another reason why he was a Praotet to be feared; Ilya's House was a global force.
    Maybe it was time to visit his American chapter and ensure that everything was running as smoothly as if his hands were conducting it directly. And besides all of that, he really did miss the pizza.

It amuses me to no end to think about Ilya enjoying a big slice of NY style pizza. I have no idea why. The vampires in this 'verse can eat normal food with no consequence, either in nutrition or adverse affect. They do it purely for the physical enjoyment of taste and nothing more. They tend to be very pleasure-seeking, a good deal of their rituals - even feeding - revolve around it.

    Life never stopped just because you wanted it to; or even because you desperately needed it to. Time was indifferent to a man's struggle and duty never took a vacation. There was an option to give in to the temptation of isolation or the immersion into work. Vincent chose the latter while Marcus chose the former. It seemed predictable that the rookie wouldn't handle a kill like that well at all. Vincent wasn't faring much better but he had the experience to not let any of it show.
    It was a dangerous game for an organization so dedicated to one ideal to have within its midsts a rogue thought. A stray infection of ethics could be disastrously fatal if it was allowed to spread. Dean recognized this crucial fact better than most. It was what brought him to Vincent's apartment that night.
    The door opened to a young man he'd never seen before with unruly, blond, wavy locks of hair nearly to his shoulders. The long sleeves of his shirt were rolled up and what looked like mud was stained in splotches over the front of his jeans. Both hands were holding a towel and were taking turns at wiping each other off.
    "Can I help you?" he asked politely to Dean.
    "I'm here for Vincent," Dean replied without the same tone of friendliness in his voice.
    "Just a moment, I'll get him for you."
    The blond turned and walked down the small hallway. "Come on in," he invited. "Hey, Vincent? There's someone here to see you."
    "Tell them I'm sorry I can't return the favor," Dean heard Vincent's reply from where he was standing in the hall.
    "You never get tired of those comments, do you?" The blond was admonishing halfheartedly.
    "And I doubt he ever will," Dean was saying as he invited himself both into the room and conversation. "Vincent, tell your friend here to take a little walk. Maybe run some errands. We need to speak."
    The blond looked rather nonplussed at his casual dismissal, though he did flick a curious glance between the pair. "It's alright, I have some projects to take to the kiln. I should be gone for a couple of hours, is that enough for you or should I paint you something while I'm at it?" The question carried a distinctive not of sarcasm beneath the friendly veneer and Vincent must have picked up on it because all he did was smile faintly to himself.
    Dean wasn't amused at all. "Leave."
    "I'll make it up to you," Vincent was promising, "I'll have dinner on by the time you get back."
    "I'll hold you to it. Now that we've labeled everything in the kitchen in braille, I expect I'll actually be able to eat it this time."
    "Quaint," Dean expressed his opinion of their exchange by closing the bedroom door with the blond standing outside of it.
    "Was there something you needed that a phone call couldn't have handled?" Vincent asked once they were alone.
    "Would I make the effort otherwise? You've not spoken to Marcus recently, I take it." Deans eyes briefly glanced about the spartan room, he'd never been in Vincent's apartment but somehow the stark blandness of it suited the blind hunter.
    "Not recently, no. He asked for time off, I'm not going to pry."
    "I have," Dean continued on as if Vincent had never spoken. "He tells me you had a juvenile to deal with. Why was I not informed?"
    He watched as the snowy white of Vincent's cheeks reddened slightly and he made the educated assumption that it wasn't embarrassment that drove the coloration. Vincent still had much to learn about concealing his emotions.
    "I didn't think it was necessary to trouble you with it."
    Vincent was lying, the only thing that eluded Dean was the why. Personal pride would be harmless, personal moral objection would be an entirely different matter. It was his mission tonight to find out which side Vincent belonged to and deal with it accordingly. Marcus had already been dealt with; an injured pride was not an easy thing to nurse but it was relatively harmless to the cause. "It's police, Vincent," Dean reminded him.
    "I know. I also know every agent gets grilled and sent through the psych department for it. I've been busy, I'm sorry I didn't feel like penciling in a therapy session followed by a game of twenty questions. I'm guessing you're not here to ask me how I'm sleeping at night."
    "I always knew your mouth would need to be fixed," Dean muttered.
    "Well, you know how I feel about dentists."
    "I need you to tell me exactly what transpired," Dean went on. He had learned the long ago that the best way to deal with Vincent was to ignore his sarcasm. They had brought Vincent up in the Order after he was found as an orphan. If it was up to him he would have gotten rid of the problematic hunter long ago. Sadly it was, in fact, not up to him.
    "It's all in the report, of course Marcus typed it up so you'll need to take it up with him if it's not to your liking."
    "I have, and now I'm here taking it up with you. I know it's confusing but do try and keep up. Now, start at the beginning and don't leave anything out this time."
    Dean had to smile at the frown pulling at Vincent's lips, but he was more concerned about his demeanor.
    "What are you really here for, Dean? What is it you want to hear? That I've never heard a child crying for her father? Well, I have. The only difference is I've never killed a child's father right in front of them before. Let's not forget to mention listening to her die afterward. Marcus missed her heart," Vincent went on, his voice almost casual despite the grim topic. He was trying to keep it together and appear unphased by the events. "The dose of silver was plenty for her body, but it wasn't quick. I held my hand," Vincent's voice broke finally, "over her mouth so she couldn't even scream. So you had better not be here to tell me I'm not allowed to feel some kind of remorse."
    He had been hoping Vincent was simply struggling with a wounded pride that he had felt something after that event. Clearly there was more to it than that. This would have to be dealt with carefully. The Order couldn't afford for one of its own to suffer a sudden fit of moral objection during a crisis situation."You disposed of a monster, nothing more."
    "She was a child!" Vincent was on his feet now and even though his eyes were not fixed on Dean they still held a barely contained fire. "You can tell me it's my job, you can eve tell me it's for mankind's protection and survival; but you cannot tell me how I'm supposed to feel about it! I don't care what she was, beast or human, she was a child!"
    "Vincent, please, you're embarrassing yourself."
    "Oh I plan to do much more than that."
    "Is that a threat?" Dean sounded far more amused with the idea than concerned.
    "It's a warning."
    Dean laughed. "And what do you intend to do, Vincent, quit? I'm sure we'll get along fine without you. You're one man," he drawled out, rather satisfied with himself, "you might want to think about what you would be getting yourself into before you get all self righteous on me. I know we don't see eye to eye--" Vincent snorted an interruption, "we don't always agree," Dean continued on, his voice a bit strained, "but I know you, Vincent. I know you have a deep sense of justice and I know once this passes you'll understand that this is all for the greater good."
    "I doubt that."    
    Dean smiled. "That was your first child, but I can guarantee you it won't be your last. Who knows, you may even begin to enjoy it."
    The blow came so fast that Dean was more impressed with Vincent's skills than angry that his subordinate had just landed a left hook against his jaw.
    "Get out!" Vincent was yelling. "Get out! Get out or so help me...I'll kill you."
    Dean lifted a hand to massage at his jaw, smiling to himself. "It will get better. You just needed to get that out of your system." With that said he left Vincent to stew over what had just transpired. The answer left him dissatisfied with the prodigy hunter. Sad; Vincent had such promise. On the way out he passed the clay spattered blond and he had to smile cryptically his way. It was time to pay Marcus another visit. Vincent needed a leash.

    It never really did seem to matter. He could pretend that it did, he could even believe it for a while, but in the end, when it came down to it, it never mattered. The Underkind were the Underkind and he had a sworn duty to protect humanity from their dark and tortured souls. Still, Vincent couldn't comprehend how killing children had anything to do with it all. It was what that child would grow into, he mused, that gave his organization the fear that drove them to kill, what were in Vincent's mind, innocents. It didn't make any of this any easier and he imagined it never would. Despite the lectures, despite the hours on end of horror stories of what these beasts were capable of, and despite his personal experience with their terrifying strength, Vincent could still not ascribe to the belief that they should be slaughtered before proven guilty. Of course, it was a fact that none of these beasts could live a normal life, they were by nature violent and aggressive and that could not change no matter how hard any of them willed it. Vincent knew that. He also knew that having these thoughts were dangerous and by the tone his superior had with him tonight he was in trouble. What kind of trouble was anyone's guess.
    It wouldn't do to have Gabriel come home to no supper, so he pushed the nagging thoughts out of his mind for the meantime and made his way to the kitchen with one hand along the wall to guide him. Before he could get started on even selecting what to make the door opened and he could hear Gabriel down the hall sound out a notice of his arrival. So much for having dinner ready, but more importantly Vincent was concerned with how he might look. Gabriel only knew that he worked as a translator for the government and that was all he could ever know about him. Being in this vulnerable state was not wholly conducive to keeping it that way.
    "I don't smell dinner cooking, Vincent," Gabe was admonishing lightly as he made his way into the kitchen.
    "I was just about to start when you came in. Have a preference or do I have to choose what we're having?" His voice was light and unconcerned, years of practice made him adept at lying. Whether that was something he should be proud of or not was a topic of thought he didn't want to face right now.
    "Pasta. Three cheese stuffed shelled pasta with marinated and roasted chicken, baby peas and a twice baked mashed potato on the side." Vincent couldn't see Gabriel's face but he heard the smile in his voice.
    "Ha ha, very funny. Mac'n cheese it is." He reached for the cupboard above and felt along the label to ensure it was the right one.
    "You're a horrible man, I hope you know," Gabriel chided harmlessly.
    Vincent cringed before he could stop himself. "I know."
    "Whoa, wait. That sounded a little too heavy. What's going on?" Abruptly there was a hand on Vincent's shoulder. Trust Gabriel to know when something was off, though right now Vincent was cursing the ability.
    "You're reading too into it," Vincent replied. He was making light of it with varying degrees of success. All that was required was for Gabriel to buy into it.
   "Am I?" Gabriel didn't sound all that convinced.
   "You are. Now, if you don't want Mac'n'cheese you should stop the interrogation. I can handle pasta." The debate was over. He might have let himself slip but he knew Gabe well enough to know that he wouldn't press any further.
    "This has to be some kind of extortion," Gabe complained before releasing his grip on Vincent's shoulder. "Alright, you win. I really am not in the mood for processed cheese tonight."

Chapter 2

    Hangovers were one thing, this was something completely different. Warren barely knew who he was when consciousness finally came to call on him. With a wide blink he looked up at the rusted ceiling. It appeared he was in a warehouse of some kind. Sitting up, his hands ran across the over sized flannel shirt that had been put on him; if he remembered correctly the last time he was conscious he was also undressed. The memories came flooding back at a dizzying pace and it struck him odd that he was waking up at all. If someone had killed his commanding officer he wouldn't have taken the sorry bastard in.
    "There's tea brewing if you're interested." Her voice was curt and to the point, not at all one he'd expect from a nurse and for good reason; she wasn't one. Her lips were pursed and both hands were on her slender hips as she glared daggers at him from across the makeshift room. "Get up and get dressed, you have a pack to maintain."
    "I do not get to 'ave some privacy?" Warren asked. A brow lifted to punctuate the question.
    "I've already seen you naked, remember?"
    Warren flinched.
    "I remember."
    "Good, because I have no intention of letting you forget."
    As he got to his feet from the bed he noticed pants weren't part of the attire he'd been dressed in for the meantime. It was by some miracle that the flannel shirt went down enough to cover him. "Fine, but do I get to at least know who is 'olding the whip?"
    "My name is Ira," was her curt response. She was obviously ignoring the whip comment.
    "Alright, Ira, I am--"
    "Warren Bancroft, I know."
    Startled, his brows furrowed as if to ask how she already knew that before a hand snatched up at his neck.
    "Where are they?" Warren barked. Despite his state of dishevelment and undress he still kept an air of command and dignity about him.
    "On the table. Get dressed, we have some work to do."
    "Wait just a minute," his hand lifted to stop her from grabbing up his tattered clothing. "I do not 'ave anything to do except get out of 'ere and go home. I am sorry about, euh..."
    "Jonathan," Ira snapped, grabbing up his clothing and tossing it at his face.
    Warren caught the clothing and held it at his chest. "Jonathan, but I 'ad nothing to do with it. He attacked me, I did nothing but defend myself. I certainly do not 'ave to do anything but apologize again and take my leave. Unless you want a shot at me."
    She seemed to be contemplating it as he stepped into his torn pants. He looked ridiculous. Ira's lips twitched, they seemed to be fighting off an amused smile and losing.
    "What?" Warren demanded, trying to look dignified in tattered jeans and an over sized flannel shirt.
    "No, nothing. You look wonderful."
    "Well it is not like I 'ave all my clothing 'ere to change into. Thank you for the shirt, but whoever it belongs to is much bigger than I am."
    "It was Jonathan's. I'd offer you his pants too but he was much taller than you."
    Warren saw something flicker in her eyes and took a guess that it was remorse. It should have been her in that fight. Jonathan had left her in charge of the perimeter that evening but she had gotten caught at work. Fall was always a hectic time of year for the fashion industry but that was not an excuse. Jonathan was dead and she felt the weight and burden of his death squarely on her slender shoulders.
    "I'm sorry," Warren murmured again.
    "You've said that already and it hasn't changed anything. Stop talking, start doing. If you are truly sorry you'll do the right thing and take his place."
    "I still do not understand. I killed 'im, 'ow am I supposed to take 'is place? And take what place? If you want any of my cooperation you will stop doing and start talking." Warren's arms folded at his chest.
    "You already know what we are, what you are. I'm sure you're not dense enough to think society accepts or acknowledges us, so we stick together. Jonathan held us together as a pack, he was our leader and our protector. Now it's your turn."
    "Or what?" Warren asked belligerently. He still wasn't convinced he had any obligation to do anything for these people, whoever they were.
    "Or I kill you and take your place." She didn't seemed at all bothered by the prospect.
    "That is ridiculous. If I do not want the position you are welcome to take it and let me leave."
    "And send the message to this pack that anyone may come and go as they wish. No. I'll take the leadership the way it has been handed down for generations in packs. So you have a choice, take responsibility for your actions or face the consequences."
    "That is not a choice," Warren grumbled. "Fine, fine. I will stay 'ere and play leader until you realize it would be better if you just let me go."
    "I thought you'd come around. First item on the agenda is to move you in. I'll accompany you to where you are staying now and get you situated here." Ira had the look of a woman who was used to handing out orders and keeping a system working smoothly. Warren caught himself staring quizzically at her. The problem was she caught him too. "What?"
    "I was just wondering what your job is in this pack. Where you Jonathan's...." he let that trail off, a little afraid of asking it outright.
    "Second in command, you mean?" Ira filled in for him what he'd left out with a slender ebony brow raising as if she was convinced that had not been what he was about to say.
    "Ah. Lead the way, then."
    It felt ridiculous to walk through the city in tattered and stained clothing with a woman who looked like she belonged running a corporate office. He had to say, though, she had a good taste in clothing. Her skirt flared out at the bottom like a vase tipped upside down and the tailored suit coat and blouse completed the stern but together outfit. All that was missing was a bun on top of her head, but instead her hair was relaxed and hanging about her shoulders like wavy, velvet black curtains. And the way she walked...
    Abruptly he pulled his eyes away and found other, less dangerous, things to stare at. It was a good couple of blocks worth of walking before they reached a subway terminal and if he wasn't just imagining it he would guess that Ira was enjoying his immense discomfort. He looked homeless and the people around him acted as if he was about to try and snatch up their belongings. Many of them seemed to be curiously interested at the oddity of a homeless man and a business woman together.
    "Which is your stop," she was asking him.
    "I'll let you know." His reply was gruff and to the point but it seemed to suffice for her almost as if she was gracefully sliding into her role as second in command already. Even if Ira had a strong personality, to put it lightly, he still found himself impressed by her willingness to change over to his command. Were they to change places he would not be so easily swayed over. In fact, he was sure he would kill anyone who harmed his commanding officer, not submit himself to their new leadership. Evidently he had much to learn about lycan pack mentality.
    The car jostled its way under the channel and into Manhattan. The pair of them rode in silence along the way. Warren had very little he wanted to say to her and the feeling went both ways. At the very least it seemed that Ira was keeping to herself out of a lack of anything productive to say to him. Warren was brooding, for the most part. Not long after they reached the island they were changing trains to run north of Times Square along the east side of central park. Of course from under ground the only way you had of knowing your location by the stops they continuously called out. Warren absently watched the tiles changing with each stop until they reached his.
    It wasn't so much that he 'let her know' that it was their stop as he just simply got up and walked out and expected her to follow. If she wanted to play this game of follow the leader he might as well give her something to do. He was more interested in seeing if she would follow his lead at all or if this was all just some clever ruse to get his back turned just enough for her to slide a knife in it. Seemed a bit ridiculous to go through this sort of trouble just to kill a man who had wronged you, but women, in his mind, could be very crafty and evidently took more pleasure in the ruse than the actual retaliation.

    "You know, you're not a very personable leader," Ira commented as she caught up. From the tone of her voice Warren guessed she wasn't entirely thrilled with his method of 'letting her know'. He tried not to smile.
    "You could always relieve me of my duties," he quipped back, perhaps a little too hopeful.
    "Oh no, I wouldn't do that to you." Warren didn't like the menacing tone in her voice, but he couldn't help but notice the way she was looking at him. It made him decidedly uncomfortable.
    "What?"
    "You really don't want to stay with us." It was a simple observation on her part. "Why?"
    "Do you even 'ave to ask? This entire situation is...delicate," it was all he could think to say.
    "That isn't the truth, at least not all of it. You'll tell me eventually," Ira concluded and seemed to be changing the topic.
    "I am sure," Warren snorted under his breath. He had no intention of disclosing anything, least of all to her. Not to mention he disliked that tone of hers that suggested she knew what he'd do before he even did. Who was she to dictate his life? If anything, wasn't he supposed to be the leader in this very awkward relationship?
    Shoving those thoughts aside he led the way down the crowded avenue toward his old apartment that he was, for lack of better words, growing out of. It came to his shock to see the stoop crisscrossed with yellow tape. There was still an officer at the steps but Warren had lived long enough in this world to know trouble when he smelled it. With a quick movement he grabbed Ira by the arm and tugged her back into the alleyway.
    "Warren what are you--"
    "Shh," he commanded sharply. "That's my apartment."
    Ira was bright and caught on to his meaning in short order. "I see. Is there something I should know, Mr. Bancroft?"
    "You know exactly what I do at this point," he muttered, eyes locked on the window above the stoop as if it were a portal for information. "I know one other thing."
    "And what is that?"
    "I am going to need to buy new clothes."
