Vincent's left temple throbbed mercilessly and he could feel the wet trickle running down all the way to his neck and knew he was bleeding. With a hissed curse he threw all his weight against the wall behind him just to remain standing. "Marcus?!"
    No response. The air stunk of spilled blood; lycan blood. Oh they had been right about there being a wolf living in this apartment complex but evidently sending just two of their members was not enough. A shaking hand lifted to where blood was still oozing from the gash in his forehead and once again checked for bite marks. None, same as last time. He had to be sure.
    A crash brought him out of his needless worry.
    "Marcus?" Vincent grunted as he pushed himself away from the wall. His body gave a protest to the movement but he ignored the complaints. They had been separated after the initial attack in the living room; Mr. Sanders apparently didn't live alone. Vincent had dealt with the unexpected party but Marcus was not with him then and he wasn't sure where he was now.
    "Vince?" The voice was coming from behind him.
    Vincent whirled around with enough force to quite nearly send his precarious balance over the edge. A hand caught him by the arm but before he could get a question on his lips the hand jerked him hard to the side just as the sensation of movement registered from his right. "You didn't deal with him?!"
    "That's what I was about to tell you!" Marcus yelled back, dragging his partner out of the reach of the half-transformed beast snarling in the middle of the living room floor.
    "Then I will," Vincent's voice was now unnervingly calm. He pulled away from Marcus who was flanking the half-crouched figure as he moved around to its other side. Based on the low snarl he estimated he was no more than three feet away. Plenty close to get a quick swipe in. To the observer it would seem as if the silver dagger had just appeared in Vincent's left hand. A quiet breath helped clear his mind. The battle ground was no place for distraction.
    "Vincent!"
    The blind hunter was already moving by the time Marcus could yelp. He had heard the talons scratching on the bare wood floor and ducked as the beast leaped for him. With his right foot pivoting his left lifted out to the side in a quick flip kick, the top of his boot impacted the creature beneath the ribs as he flew past. The wall groaned with the collision of the massive beast. "Don't try that again," Vincent facetiously admonished.
    The hunter took a step forward and listened to the creature as he gained his footing again.
    "You're not as senseless as you look," it grunted in a warped sound of a voice.
    "I'll have to take your word on that. Tell me, are you as ugly as you sound?" As he taunted his right hand disappeared into the confines of his jacket.
    The only reply was an angry snarl. Vincent braced himself. The jarring force sent him sprawling to the floor with a wet mass of thick hair and sinewy muscle pinning him to the cold floor. He could smell the creature's breath and tried not to cough and gag. The sting of sharp talons on his shoulders drew a brief cringe. Marcus was yelping like a startled child.
    "I'll show you ugly, Hunter."
    "Do you know what the interesting thing about silver is?" Vincent asked almost casually as he impaled the sharp needle of the syringe hidden in his right hand into the howling beast. "It comes in all shapes and sizes. Silver Nitrate," he further explained as his thumb depressed the plunger and pushed the clear liquid into the wolf atop him.
    With a howl of unworldly pain the creature released its death grip on the blind man beneath him and rolled to the ground with the deadly syringe sticking up from his side. Fur gave way to skin and back to fur again as he writhed and thrashed on the ground, his body switching between human and wolf at a dizzying pace. Claws racked the wooden floor drawing out deep gashes with each pass until finally all of him stilled. Vincent knew at that point it was over.
    With a sigh the hunter got to his feet and brushed himself off; job well done. From the distance, perhaps in the other room down the hall, he heard a noise that made his blood chill through his veins. It wasn't a threatening sound, at least not physically. It threatened something much more precious to The Order; it threatened his sanity and his conviction.
    "Daddy?"
    He'd been hit many times that night; by fists, by claws, by kicks, and by something he assumed had once been a chair leg. Nothing ever had hit him quite this hard or stole so much of his breath.
    "Daddy? Daddy?! DADDY!"
    The small voice was getting louder and Vincent knew she had run to the fallen corpse on the ground that had once been her father. He'd been taught that these things happened. Lycans had the ability to mate both with humans and other lycans. Vampires did not have that kind of a threat to a man's sanity. He also knew what he was supposed to do in a situation like this but it was just as clear to him when faced with it he couldn't follow through.
    As it turned out he didn't have to. The sound was loud enough to jar him out of his shock and louder still to force him back a few steps. Though he'd never use one he knew all too well what they sounded like. He knew the target without even having to ask. Marcus has shot her.
    "I...it..." Marcus stammered, obviously underestimating what killing a child in cold blood would do to a man.
    "You were following procedure," Vincent heard himself saying without any real conviction.

The courthouse was located nestled between towering buildings; tucked away from the bustle of the city. Inside the paint was peeling in small patches along the walls and a tile or two were missing from the floor. Not the most prestigious assignment he’d ever been given but if one thing could be said of the government translator it would certainly be that he did not place any value in aesthetics.

            “We’ll need to take your ah…”

            “Walking stick?” Vincent offered on a hunch. With a press of his thumb and a flick of his wrist the metal, collapsible, and lightweight vision aide folded up to a size no bigger than a good sized pen.

            “Ah…yes, thanks. An officer will be right around to guide you.”

            Her voice was pleasant enough. Mid-forties, Vincent guessed. African American; possibly from the east coast. There wasn’t a need for a guide. Vincent had been in this courthouse enough times to have the basic floor plan memorized, but he allowed himself to be led all the same.

            The case wasn’t particularly interesting today. A couple was filing for a divorce and it seemed neither of them spoke a good deal of English. A case could be made that they had the concept of swearing down enough to guest star on an episode of Jerry Springer, though.

            “Thank god. Finally someone who can understand what the hell these two are saying,” it was William speaking. Vincent knew the bailiff through his constant court appointments.

            “Nice to see you too,” Vincent said, allowing for a hint of sarcasm to creep into his voice. It was his standard for expressions like that.

             His work started almost as soon as the words left his lips. A flurry of very angry Mandarin rose up from both sides of the room.

            “See what I mean?”

            “About as well as anyone can see a spoken language,” Vincent replied.

            “Right, well, they’re all yours. Judge,” William was addressing the bench now, “this is our interpreter.”

            “You can speak this gibberish?” Vincent took note of the feminine inflection but he couldn’t quite place her voice with a name. She could be new.

            “Mandarin, yes,” Vincent answered. He was used to the slight disbelief people expressed when they learned he could speak a multitude of foreign languages; Mandarin included. As Marcus put it he looked ‘too white’ to speak any language other than English. If only he knew what ‘white’ meant he might have a better understanding. Apparently it was the color of his hair and skin. The doctors he had been taken to as a child had a name for it; albinism. How he looked had never been much of a concern for him, though he did understand it had more of an impact on others.

            “Excellent,” the judge was saying. “Let’s get on with it then. You can start by telling both Mr. and Mrs. –Teeang,” she struggled to decide on how to pronounce the name, “to be silent until spoken to.”

            “Of course, your Honor.”

            Mandarin wasn’t his strongest language and the unhappily married couple spoke an odd dialect of it; he did manage to get the point across for them to quiet down, though.

            “Do I dare ask what has brought the both of you here today?” She nodded her head toward Vincent before catching herself, but he was already firing away in the couple’s native language. How anyone could make sense out of those sounds was beyond her comprehension.

            “He is a pig!” Vincent translated rather animatedly. His voice had even changed in pitch. “He brings home young women all night. I have the right to be rid of him. He broke the rules. He is guilty!”

            “She is a liar!” Again Vincent’s voice changed to indicate who he was translating for. It almost made him feel like he had some sort of split personality disorder. “Those women work for me, she is just an old, jealous woman. She’s crazy.”

            “I am not crazy, he’s a pig!”

            “Enough!” This time it was the judge yelling. “One at a time.”

            Vincent translated the judge’s orders.

            “Let’s start with the wife. Do you have proof of his infidelity?”

            “Proof? I have my two eyes! I have seen him with these girls. Pig.”

            “I’m sorry Mrs. Teeang--“

            “Tiang!”

            “Tiang, but you have to show me some kind of evidence.”

            There was an outburst of rapid Mandarin but Vincent remained silent.

            “Well, Mr. Yegorov?” The judge inquired.

            “I’m not sure I’m allowed to say those things to a judge, Your Honor.”

            “I see. Tell Mrs. Tiang she should watch what she says.”

            The message was relayed and Mrs. Tiang didn’t speak up to protest them. The rest of the procedure would not go as smoothly and more than once he had to remind the animate woman to refrain from yelling obscenities.

            It was nearing mid evening by the time Vincent was finished with his court duties for the day. None of the other participants were nearly as animated as the first couple of the day. The air outside the courthouse was chilly and carried with it the scent of autumn.

            Time to get to work.

            Vincent’s cell was flipped open and lifted to his ear.

            “Marcus, what do you have for me today? Are we finally going to be on assignment together?”

            “We’ve got us a mad dog on the south side. Where you at? Need a ride or what?”

            “You’ll learn,” Vincent replied, a hint of amusement was in his voice.

            “Heh, sure. I didn’t want to babysit your ass tonight anyway.”

            Vincent was grinning as he stepped off in the direction of the nearest subway terminal. He had just ruffled some feathers.

            “You’re the rookie, remember?”

            He hung up after getting the exact address. At this time of night the subway was crowded with people on their way home from work. After a few bumps and mumbled apologies he found himself a place to stand and something to hold onto and waited for the car to begin moving. A quick pat of his long coat assured him he remembered to get his walking stick back.

            America was the land of opportunities, or so he’d been told. Any man who put his back into his work could make a healthy living in this country of freedoms. Warren felt a little less than optimistic about his chances here, but he knew his chances back in France were a great deal worse. There was only so many times you could change your name and birth date before someone began to catch on; and only so many times you could claim to have an uncanny resemblance to an old relative someone once remembered.

            New York City was not his first choice of places to live. Saint Louis was promising and so was New Orleans. Montreal was far too cold for his tastes and what the locals spoke could not in good conscience be called French. No matter where his travels took him he always found that the cities weren’t big enough for a man to disappear into. That is until he stumbled upon the Big Apple.

            A man could truly disappear in a city of this size. If your face became too familiar it was a simple matter to move to the island or out in Queens and you would once again blend back into society.

            At the moment he was attempting to find a new apartment and liked to do his scouting at night. It wasn’t so much that he cared about the view; it was more about what went on in the neighborhoods at night. The noisier the better. A bonus if it was located near machinery of some kind, or perhaps a cemetery where strange noises would be written off as an over active imagination.

            It was well past midnight when his casual searching brought him into the Industrial district and from the sounds going on all around him even at this late hour it looked promising. Not far off there was the sound of a train rumbling by. Oddly, he noticed, there was a park not far off nestled between construction sites. Probably a vestige of a neighborhood that used to be here, he guessed.         

            His stroll took him through the park; the old benches were rusted and forlorn like the rest of the area. This kind of rundown scenery was oddly appealing to him. His senses were preoccupied on taking in the sights and he didn’t notice the rustle of leaves and snapping of twigs until it was far too late to do anything but react.

            The blow came at his left side, a steel toed boot cracked against ribs pulling out a low grunt from Warren’s chest. He used the momentum to roll once he hit the mossy ground and took that inertia right up to standing again. Now he could see his assailant. A man in what looked to be his late thirties with dirty blond hair cropped short stood in a ready stance facing him. The precise state of his beard indicated to Warren that the man wasn’t homeless. It begged the question as to why he was attacking him.

            The low growl answered that. With a few sniffs to the air he confirmed what his ears were telling him: a Wolf. “I am not ‘ere to pick a fight,” Warren grunted. His side was aching but already it had begun to heal internally. “Whatever it is you think you ‘ave against me I would ask that you reconsider it.” Warren wasn’t a push over. He had served in two world wars and had witnessed enough horrors to last several men their lifetimes. If he could avoid a bloody confrontation he would certainly try.

            “You’re trespassing,” the other Wolf said. Warren would have expected him to sound more aggressive but the other man’s tone was almost formal; certainly very matter of fact.

            “I did not know that I was. This city is new to me; I am only looking for a place to settle down quietly. I am sure you can understand that desire.” Wasn’t it the goal of their kind to find some kind of peace between the risings of the full moon?

            “You’re no pup,” the stranger pointed out. “You should understand the rules. You’ve trespassed on our ground. You know where we hide now. I can’t possibly allow that kind of a threat to simply waltz out of here, now can I?”

            “I would not presume to tell you what you can and cannot do. I would suggest, ‘owever, that you stand down.”

            “And why is that?” The man made a showy gesture of looking around. “You have an army stashed around somewhere?”

            “You know that I do not.”

            “Then let’s get this over with.”

            Warren didn’t have time to respond before his opponent was leaping at inhuman speeds toward him.

            Vincent let out a sigh of relief as he stepped out of the subway terminal and breathed in the fresh night air. The relief turned a little sour when he heard the sound of a familiar voice coming up behind him.

            “You’re late,” Marcus said.

            “Actually I’m right on time. You work for me, not the other way around,” Vincent reminded him.

            “I thought we both worked for the same guy.”

            “Ultimately, yes. But he’s not here right now, is he? Like it or not, you work for me. Now, where exactly is this rogue dog?” Vincent was cutting the argument short. He already had to show Marcus his place before back at the complex and he hated repeating himself. Marcus wasn’t a bad guy but he tended to put far too much stock in appearances and didn’t think a blind man could tie his own shoes let alone do the kind of things the job required of them. Vincent had decided to make it a personal goal to constantly prove his partner wrong.

            “Need me to hold your hand?” Marcus was clearly not pleased with being cut off from a perfectly good chance at an argument.

            “Only if you intend to buy me dinner,” Vincent quipped with a light smile on his face.

            Marcus grunted his appraisal of that offer with a few choice words. “Just try and keep up. I ain’t going to watch both our backs and I know you ain’t gonna be watching mine.”

            Vincent merely continued to smile as he followed the pattering sound of Marcus’ footsteps; his ability to follow was uncanny. Marcus had already accused him of pretending to be blind, though what purpose that would serve was beyond Vincent’s ability to figure out. He’d never had to prove his blindness to anyone before Marcus and doubted he’d need to prove it to anyone after. His partner was just a very special kind of person.

            “You did remember to bring the weapons, right?” Vincent asked. It would be a terribly unfortunate thing to confront a wild animal without them.

            “Yeah, of course I did. I’m not stupid.”

            “I never said you were. Mind handing some of them over?”

            “So you grill me and forget to bring your own damn gear?” Marcus sounded irritated.

            “I was in court all day, I can’t very well walk in there loaded down with equipment. There are laws against that kind of thing, you know. Hand it over.” Vincent’s hand latched onto his partner’s arm to halt them both in their brisk walk.

            Marcus jerked his arm out of the other’s grip with a grumble. “Fine, but you’re not getting the gun.”

            “Good. I have terrible aim. The syringe and link will do. A dagger, too, if you have one.” Vincent was surprisingly skilled at hand to hand combat and didn’t like to rely on weapons to subdue a target, but when he had to choose he preferred something light and agile. After Marcus unceremoniously handed over the gear he thanked him facetiously before tucking away the equipment.

            Not long after the exchange, Vincent held up a hand to stop Marcus, his first two fingers lifting from a closed fist to indicate that his order shouldn’t be questioned. The smell was light, almost too faint to be noticed but Vincent’s sense of smell was heightened far beyond an average human’s. “We’re getting close.”

            “No shit, Sherlock. His home ain’t that far away.” Marcus grumbled something after that sounded to Vincent a good deal like ‘I knew I’d end up babysitting’.

            “Good. He doesn’t travel too far from home, then. The pair of them rolled down the slope of a small hill, Warren grunting as his back collided with a random rock protruding from the ground. Both men’s hands had transformed, long and slender claws extended from where finger nails once were. Even their eyes had changed. Warren’s took on a dark crimson while the stranger’s were a golden hazel. It was fortunate that the full moon was a good week away or Warren would have had to be concerned with losing all control to the Wolf.

            A snarl made him think his opponent wasn’t so concerned about maintaining control. They had stopped their rolling with Warren pinning the man to the ground but the shoulders beneath his hands were shifting in a sickening fashion. He had just enough time to thrust himself back before the other Wolf lashed out with more muscular arms than he had just a moment ago. With a cringe and a sinking feeling Warren realized to win this fight he had to give in to his baser instincts.

            While his opponent writhed on the ground in the midst of the change he followed suit. Joints popped and twisted out of shape. Muscle grew and shrunk, undulating beneath his skin that was now sprouting fur. In a moment both men were nowhere to be seen and in their places stood two wolves snarling viciously at each other.

            The light colored wolf lunged first, his gaping maw aimed for the ebony one’s neck. Again they latched together with claws raking deep against flesh and tumbled to the ground. A mixture of snarls and yelps filled the air over the course of the next tense twenty minutes. Neither of them had a significant upper hand in this fight and they were both limping and exhausted by the end of it.

            It had to be finished and soon. Warren understood that even as his mind reverted to a more primal state full of instinct and sensation rather than thought and tactics. This had to end or he would be the one to die tonight.

            “Jonathan!” It was a female voice full of shock and intensity.

            Warren took the split second to attack. His jaws clamed down around the wolf’s neck and all four sets of claws dug in deep to hold on while he thrashed. Blood nearly choked him as it ran down his throat and over his muzzle to matt down his fur. The other wolf struggled admirably but Warren refused to let go; refused to die. It took a solid minute for the other body to go limp beneath him and even then he still didn’t let go. It wasn’t until hands were pulling him off that he finally let go.

            The woman whose voice he had heard was yanking on him by the scruff of his neck and she showed no reverence as she tossed him aside. Her hands were next digging into the neck of the fallen wolf, searching desperately for a pulse. When none was there to be found she did something that Warren found highly perplexing. She bowed.

            It took a great deal out of him to reshape himself into a human form. He realized belatedly that his clothing was ripped and nowhere to be found on his person.

            “What are you doing,” Warren asked. He got to his feet gingerly, both hands ducking down between his legs to provide some measure of decency.

            “You killed him,” she stated simply as if it would mean something significant to the foreigner.

            “He attacked me,” Warren defended himself. “I ‘ad no choice. ‘e gave me no choice.”

            “You don’t understand. You killed our leader. Now you will take his place.”

            “I…what? I am not sure you understand. I ‘ave no desire to take ‘is place. I…” Warren was cut off from his protest by a light groan. The fight had taxed his body too much. With an ungraceful stumble he attempted to keep his balance but ended up toppling straight to the ground in front of her feet. Both hands managed to stay clasped to his genitals but decency was the least of his concerns now.

The Nine Temperments
Active or Passive
Law or Chaos
Approach or Withdraw
Flexible or Stubborn
Intense or Calm
Happy or Upset
Distracted or Driven
Persistent or Irresolute
Sensitive or Blunt

Vincent
Passive - Vincent is anything but lazy but he does better with fine motor skill activities rather than hyperactive activities. When he's not in training he's 'reading' or listening to music/radio talk shows.
Law - he has a schedule and he prefers to stick to it. The man can tell time without needed to consult a clock and rarely needs an alarm to wake him.
Withdraw - he has learned the hard way what rushing in can do. 'Look before you leap' doesn't quite apply so Vincent listens and feels before he responds. Only exception is in a fight where instinct and training give him quick reflexes and not enough time to think through every action.
Stubborn - simple answer to how Vincent deals with change is that he doesn't. Even if it is necessary for his type of work. Just because he seems to be going along with the change in plans does not in any way mean he enjoys it. If it's for the greater good he'll keep his complaints to himself.
Calm - almost disturbingly so. It takes a bit to move him to intense emotion but when you do you had better stand back.
Upset- content is probably a better word. Vincent is neither overly optimistic or overly pessimistic though he does lean more toward the latter.
Driven - the task is not done until it's done. Vincent can stay on target despite external distractions.
Persistent - he sticks to the plan with his nose to the grindstone. Mostly.
Sensitive - when not focused on a particular task he can be very sensitive to noise and touch. Vincent uses these traits to aid his fighting ability.

Gabriel
Active - though not in the sense that he's always running around wildly. If you've ever tried to throw clay on a wheel you know it is anything but a calm and uneventful process. He puts energy into his creations and puts in a good deal of hours at the kiln.
Chaos - schedules are all well and good but freedom of expression is much better. Gabriel might occasionally sleep in or go to bed at an odd hour due to being up all night with the kiln. Coffee is for the times when life meets sleep schedule and bulldozes over it.
Approach - Gabriel is a very friendly and outgoing sort, at least when it's safe to do so. He seldom makes any lasting friends for safety's sake, but he isn't shy to talk to people even if he doesn't allow himself the luxury of getting close.
Flexible - an artist very well has to be. When a pot explodes in the kiln you start over and learn from the mistake. When tempers explode you adapt to calm the situation. Gabriel fits this mold better than most. He is a natural peace keeper.
Intense - when he's happy it shows, when he's down it also shows. Gabriel doesn't throw fits of rage or tantrums but he is excitable, particularly when a student finally gets the hang of pulling handles.
Happy - even if at times he feels he has no right to be. There are dark times but on the whole Gabriel is optimistic. Or at the very least he doesn't always let his darker moods show as much as he does his better moods.
Distracted - not to say he can't finish a task but his mind does have the tendency to wander if nothing is holding its attention.
Persistent - adversity to a task only makes it more worthwhile to complete. The harder the clay fights him the more enjoyable the product is when he finally masters it. Gabriel doesn't back down from challenges that he knows he can meet and conquer.
Sensitive - he can tell the moods around him and has a keen sense of smell and eyesight thanks to his wolf.
-- He's almost exactly opposite of Vincent. Huh. Didn't see that coming and neither did the Hunter. lol blind joke, I slay me.

Ilya
Passive - only time Ilya is aroused to action is when his House needs protection or discipline. The Patron is content with a good book and a better glass of wine.
Law - he keeps his own schedule but it is fairly routine.
Withdraw - he likes to watch first and approach later when he feels he has the upper hand by knowing more about the other party than they know about him. Ilya is very wary around those he doesn't know anything about and soon finds out everything he can at his first convenience.
Stubborn - he is used to having things go his way and is very abhorrent to having his plans change without his notice.
Calm - cold as ice is more aptly put. The Vampire has no difficulty keeping his emotions to himself almost to the point where it is anyone's guess if he feels them at all anymore.
Happy - if by happy you mean content with what he has and where he is. He is by no means 'bubbly' or 'giddy'. Ever.
Driven - barely anything can distract the man from his goal. It is little wonder how he has come from being a peasant in the house of Petrov to being its Praotet.
Persistent - it goes along with what was said for driven.
Blunt - it isn't that he is oblivious to his surroundings it's just that he doesn't care. If he's reading a good book it wont matter how many times you shout his name he isn't going to hurry through his reading any faster for you. And you'll probably shut up the second time you yell with collapsed vocal chords. He will get to you on his time, not yours.

Warren
Active - remnants from life as a soldier. If he's not working out he's carving furniture or sanding pieces to be painted later or building something new for the pack's communal lodging.
Law - another remnant from his soldiering days. Warren gets cranky if he goes to bed late.
Approach - shoot first ask questions...never. Warren goes in with both guns blazing before questioning if that's the best course of action or not.
Stubborn - if things don't go the way he planned then god help the poor soul standing nearest him.
Intense - when he's angry you'll know it, probably because your nose is now broken.
Upset - life is miserable, you just have to try and make it less miserable for you. Warren's more of a realist than a pessimist but he does meander over into the pessimist's camp from time to time.
Driven - he has goals and will do whatever is necessary to meet them.
Irresolute - failure is not looked on well. If he can't do it right the first time then he doesn't want to do it at all. This is why when he tries to paint landscapes many brushes end up broken on the floor.
Sensitive - noise distracts him and pisses him off. Keep your music down while he tries to paint or it won't be the brushes that end up broken.

I was browsing the Romance forum on NaNoWriMo.org and found a pet peeves thread. I compiled a list of things most people seemed to hate seeing in a romance and thought I'd post them here for a reminder when I start writing. Granted the whole novel isn't going to be a love story but I am adding that element in. Here goes.

Romance Pet Peeves. What not to do.

The Big Misunderstanding: if it can be cleared up by just one of the two being sensible enough to act like adults and talk about it then it should not last the entire novel.

Insta-couples: Love at first sight is overdone. People need time to really develop feelings for each other and a good relationship doesn’t happen overnight.

Mutant Females: KNOW THE FEMALE ANATOMY.

Mutant Males: KNOW THE MALE ANATOMY.

Hyper Anatomy Focus Syndrome: It’s a serious disease that infects romance writers wherein every bodily detail that can be described gets described. No one really needs to know about throbbing parts and gooey excretions.

Flimsy Women: If they can’t tie their own shoes without a man’s help then they need to be hit by a bus and do the gene pool a favor.

Must Fix It Before The Book Ends Syndrome: Using the last five pages to fix up a relationship that has been through betrayal, and everything else under the sun, is a bad idea. If they are going to work it out it better take more than a few pages of make up sex at the very end.

Because we all have them our characters should too. I'm assembling a tentative list of some quirks to give my characters to flesh them out more.

Vincent
-Seems to always know the time without having to check a watch, and being that he's blind it makes it more fun and probably why he developed the skill.
-Enjoys having his left foot hit the top step when climbing stairs and will often readjust on the way up if he determines he will land with his right foot. Even more pleased when he starts with his left foot and ends on his left foot, so odd number of stairs are preferred.
-Orders the same meal from a local Chinese restaurant each week. General Tsao's and Moo Moo Gai Pan.
-Has the Art of War memorized. Will quote it often even if the situation really doesn't call for it.
-Cries to certain songs but will never, ever, let anyone find out about it. Usually plays his cello in private for this very reason.

Gabriel
-Twirls strands of his hair when bored or nervous.
-Likes to talk using sound effects to describe actions and anything else he can come up with a noise for.
-Enjoys coffee to the extreme, will sometimes moan with a sip when he thinks no one is around to hear him do it. And sometimes even when he knows they are if it's a good enough brand. Tea will substitute for coffee only if there isn't any of the brew to be had.
-Hopelessly oblivious to sexual innuendos and makes them often without realizing it.


Warren
-Talks with his hands. Wildly. Even when on the phone.
-Compulsively checks the dates on coins that he picks up or comes across. Any that have a date that mean something to him (i.e. anniversary date, birth date - rare since he's a werewolf and was born in the 1890's, etc.) he keeps in a separate pocket and saves. Has almost a hundred dollars stashed away in these coins ranging from pennies to silver dollars. Refuses to spend them.
-Keeps his military issued revolver in a locked case that is not to be touched, looked at, or opened by anyone. No one in the pack even knows what he keeps in there.
-Generally calls people by their last names putting some distance between himself and others, but will correct anyone who calls him by his surname.

Ira
-Collects Vera Bradley anything. Has to restrain herself when new patterns come out. Will often stop at store fronts and stare at the designs while whoever she is with walks on ahead and loses her.
-Will pick up any small rock that she deems appealing. Has her own small rock garden in the pack community lodging made up of assorted pebbles. Often makes Warren carry her trinkets in his pockets.
-Cannot stand it when people keep secrets. Will go to any length to make them talk if she believes it is in the best interests of the pack.
-Has a ring with an inner movable part that she will twirl absently from time to time.

Ilya
-Lapses into Russian while talking to himself or thinking aloud without realizing it. Sometimes while talking to other people.
-Uncontrollable urge to straighten objects that are off-kilter.

Julian
-Feels compelled to be sarcastic to everyone he meets.
-Determined to kill Warren and become the pack leader someday. Talks often about how he plans to do it.
-Exaggerated idea about his own self-importance.
-Indulges in sexual innuendos often.
